Legal_Issue: Legality of rejecting a refugee claim based on religious knowledge and conduct
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Application_Facts: Applicant's claimed religious practice and knowledge assessed by RPD member without objective criteria
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, redetermination of refugee claim
Court_Ruling: Decision overturned due to improper assessment of religious credibility
Defendant_Behavior: RPD member questioned applicant’s Christian knowledge and dismissed church involvement without fair analysis
Grounds_for_Claim: Perceived lack of Christian religious knowledge and implausible religious practice in Canada
Legal_Standard: Rigorous standard required for implausibility findings; prohibition on subjective religious testing
Assessment_Factor: Credibility of religious belief and practice, consistency of testimony, evidence of church participation
Applicable_Legislation: IRPA, sections related to refugee protection and procedural fairness
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide fair hearing, inadequate reasoning, lack of standardized assessment for religious knowledge
Review_Standard: Reasonableness, correctness for questions of law
Credibility_Assessment: Improperly based on subjective religious knowledge testing
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, church attendance records or statements, religious knowledge responses
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 96 of IRPA (decision-making authority), Section 2(a) of Charter (freedom of religion)
Application_Basis: Fear of persecution based on religion in country of origin
Evidence_Assessed: Applicant's religious knowledge, Canadian church involvement
Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugee, stay of removal, permanent resident status
Governing_Rule: A finding of implausibility must be supported by clear and convincing evidence and cannot rely on arbitrary religious tests
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of objective standards for assessing religious knowledge
Outcome: Decision referred back to a different panel for redetermination
Harm_Assessment: Risk of return to persecution due to flawed refugee determination process
Cause_Description: Rejection of refugee claim based on inadequate and biased assessment of religious knowledge and practice
Evidence_Handling: Failure to fairly consider all evidence related to religious practice in Canada
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 2(a) of the Charter, principles of procedural fairness under IRPA
Evidence_Issues: Subjective dismissal of evidence regarding religious participation without justification
Residency_Compliance: Applicant lawfully present in Canada as a refugee claimant
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient and unreasonable evaluation of religious evidence
Decision_Rationale: The decision relied on an impermissible basis for disbelief—subjective religious knowledge—without proper analysis
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to apply consistent and fair standards in evaluating religious evidence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Standard for implausibility in refugee claims involving religious persecution
